title: Can Republicans and Democrats both be right? Understanding the logic of both side's narratives
preview: How we filter for evidence our opponents are dumb and evil—and we’re blameless.
body:
*This is an edited version of* *[a piece originally published by The Liberal Patriot](https://www.liberalpatriot.com/p/its-all-the-other-sides-fault).*

Americans today live inside competing moral universes, each with its own villains, heroes, and storylines about who’s destroying the country. Scroll through your feed, talk to your friends, or turn on any partisan outlet, and you’ll find a familiar refrain: "we’re not the problem—they are." It’s often accompanied by angry, self-assured takes that if you don’t see the obvious threat the “other side” poses—and haven’t chosen correctly—there’s something wrong with you.

The truth is that there are defensible grievances in these opposing stories. Both sides can point to real injustices, real threats, and real patterns of objectionable behavior from their opponents. But regardless of whose grievances are more valid, the deeper problem for us as a country is how easily we come to harshly judge people who've reached different conclusions—seeing them as naïve, immoral, or even evil and dangerous.

This sense of moral clarity—of knowing that the “good people” are on our side—feels good. It gives us coherence and purpose in confusing times. But it also blinds us. Because in politics—as in most human conflicts—each side’s story about "who started it," who’s acting in bad faith, and who’s just defending themselves often contains various truths.

If we hope to cool our national conflict—and avert a continued slide into chaos and dysfunction—we first have to understand how both sides come to believe their side is the obviously right one. We need to see how our arrogance and refusal to listen to others' concerns keep us locked in a cycle of contempt.

#### **Can Both Sides Be Right?**

So many of us see our political opponents as clearly the "bad guys" on a slew of important issues. This was the case before 2015 but, since then, toxic polarization has [increased](https://www.pewresearch.org/politics/2022/08/09/as-partisan-hostility-grows-signs-of-frustration-with-the-two-party-system/) greatly, with a steadily increasing number of people viewing the "other side" as immoral, extreme, and dangerous, and even more [hateful](https://www.pnas.org/doi/10.1073/pnas.2001263117).

It's important to note that both "sides" can have defensible justifications for their core narratives.

Let's take Republican¹-associated grievances. Many Republicans point to Democrats’ large and rapid [attitudinal](https://archive.is/jgIkV) [shifts](https://theweek.com/politics/1002300/progressives-are-aggressors-in-the-culture-war-too) on issues like immigration, abortion, gender, policing, and more, shifts they argue haven’t been mirrored in scale on the right. These changes, compounded by what they perceive as [harsh moral judgment](https://www.vox.com/2016/4/21/11451378/smug-american-liberalism) from the left, have led many to conclude *the left caused this toxic conflict we're in; it's their fault*.

On the other side, Democrats are concerned about Trump’s contemptuous and aggressive behavior, and his seeming enjoyment of bending and breaking rules. For them, Trump's refusal to accept the 2020 election represents, in a nutshell, the dangers of having a leader with Trump's temperament. Democrats see no Democratic version of someone with Trump’s divisive personality and penchant for defying democratic norms, and this leads many to conclude *Republicans are the aggressors; they caused this mess*.

People in both groups focus on the grievances that alarm them most but often [struggle to understand](https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2019/06/republicans-and-democrats-dont-understand-each-other/592324/) what bothers their adversaries. From the outside, our opponents’ complaints can look minor, silly, or misinformed compared to our concerns, which we (naturally) see as legitimate and based in reality. The more partisan and team-based our view of things becomes, the more we risk becoming arrogant, convinced that “you’d have to be an idiot” not to see which group is worse and more at fault for all the chaos and division around us. All this serves to fan the flames of toxic polarization.

Regardless of which group’s grievances are more defensible, it's important to note that each group's grievances about the other can rest on logically defensible foundations. Admitting that this is the case doesn't mean agreeing with the "other side," and it doesn't mean one is saying "both sides are the same." It just means acknowledging that there are some truths involved in each group's primary narratives.

It's also worth considering how complex our world is. There are myriad data points and so many events unfolding around us on a daily basis that [nobody can accurately process all of it](https://kevindorst.substack.com/i/141671575/limited-attention-bayesians)—at least not in any objective, unbiased way. We thus rely on stories, stereotypes, and heuristics to help us make sense of things. Even when we agree on the same facts, our different moral framing and prioritization can lead us to entirely different views of what those facts mean—and what they portend for the future.

These points help explain how rational, well-meaning people can reason their way to polar opposite views that they believe are good and righteous—a dynamic philosopher Kevin Dorst calls “[rational polarization](https://kevindorst.substack.com/p/stranger-apologies).” If we can lower our own arrogance, we might develop greater understanding of people who possess very different values and beliefs and perhaps act in ways that [persuade](https://apokerplayer.medium.com/how-do-groups-come-to-believe-such-vastly-different-things-7cc54459dfcf) instead of inflame—even as we still [push for the causes](https://defusingamericananger.substack.com/p/can-you-resist-trump-while-also-working) we believe in.

To be clear: toxic conflict does lead to us becoming more team-based and unreasonable in our thinking. We grow to have [overly pessimistic, distorted, and catastrophizing](https://buildersmovement.org/2024/01/25/distorted-lens-how-perceptions-of-other-side-drive-toxic-polarization/) views of "them." Conflict makes us more dumb, basically. But both things can be true: our opponents are often more reasonable than we assume, AND the most angry, polarized people can be highly unreasonable.

#### **The Fog of Conflict**

Part of the difficulty in recognizing that the "other side" is more rational than we think is that the nature of the conflict can feel so simple to us. Conflict rarely feels complicated when we’re in it. Many of us simply perceive so many bad people on the other side that it's easy to conclude: *they* are the aggressors; *we* are just defending ourselves.

But these simple, black-and-white stories blind us to the complexity of the world and the people in it. As historian Geoffrey Blainey [has observed](https://defusingamericananger.substack.com/p/the-complexity-of-conflict), each side in a war tends to see history through its own eyes. Most serious conflicts have many causes, cross-currents, and [feedback loops](https://defusingamericananger.substack.com/p/how-does-our-anger-at-them-create), which makes it hard for the parties involved to ever get a clear view of the conflict. He writes that “the distinction between warmaker and peacemaker is often a mirage.”

One well-known aspect of conflict that obscures our view of people on the “other side” is the tendency to see them as [all the same](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/01402382.2025.2489869?af=R)—as a monolithic, homogeneous mass. This leads to all sorts of misunderstandings, including “[perception gaps](https://www.liberalpatriot.com/p/how-perception-gaps-fuel-americas),” which convince people that the other side is much more extreme than they actually are.

Another confusing aspect of conflict is that people in large groups always possess different traits and exhibit different behaviors. In the US, Democrats and Republicans differ—on average—in background, life experience, values, and moral priorities. This leads to differences in how each group manifests its anger and anxiety. For example, a mostly working-class, blue-collar community is likely to interact in conflict differently than a mostly college-educated group would. Each group will apply different types of social pressures on its members when it comes to their behavior and how those members approach the conflict.

And because these differences are usually substantial, each side can point to “bad things they do that we don’t do” and then treat these things as definitive proof that their opponents are the problem.

But the causes of conflict are often complex, and two groups in conflict will always contribute to it in different ways.² It’s therefore worth examining some of the ways in which Republicans and Democrats can both arrive at the view that “it’s all the other side’s fault,” depending on which events and group traits they focus on.

**1.** **Perceived support for violence**

Many people believe it’s the “other side” that’s more violent—that *they* are the ones whose supporters are more likely to endorse political violence, or at least seem more tolerant of such violence.

Many on the left believe that right-wing extremism is by far a much more serious threat than liberal-side extremism. They point to events like the Charlottesville *Unite the Right* march, the [assault on Nancy Pelosi’s husband](https://www.cnn.com/2022/10/31/politics/pelosi-attack-right-wing-conspiracy-theories-invs), murders by far-right extremists (like the [2022 Buffalo, NY, mass murder](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Buffalo_shooting) and the [2019 El Paso, TX, mass murder](https://elpasomatters.org/2025/03/30/patrick-crusius-donald-trump-aug-3-2019-walmart-mass-shooting/)), and, perhaps most prominently, [January 6](https://www.thebulwark.com/p/how-republicans-learned-to-excuse-political-violence-trump-january-6th-pardons)—the event that, to them, most embodies the violent threat posed by Trump and his diehard supporters.

On the right, many see liberals as the violent ones. Conservatives focus on different events and different manifestations of social disruptions, including things like [violence](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/oct/31/americans-killed-protests-political-unrest-acled) during the 2020 George Floyd protests, [aggressive tactics](https://www.nytimes.com/2021/10/08/us/politics/kyrsten-sinema-joe-biden.html) by progressive activists, and, most recently, the [assassination of Charlie Kirk](https://x.com/bgmasters/status/1965860238919348729). They believe too many liberals either [support or tacitly condone](https://www.newsweek.com/political-violence-left-wing-extremism-donald-trump-gaza-deportation-riots-2083162) militancy and violence.

Sometimes, both groups even find evidence of the other side’s violent nature in the same event. For example, following the assassination attempt on Trump in Pennsylvania, some of his supporters [cast blame on liberals](https://www.newsweek.com/us-vs-them-narratives-are-wrong-response-trump-shooting-opinion-1925274), while some liberals [pointed to](https://x.com/TheFungi669/status/1812347724609847496) the shooter’s past political activity to score points against Republicans.

Some people react in [cruel](https://time.com/6226946/paul-pelosi-attack-gop-response-political-discourse/) and [callous](https://www.thefp.com/p/students-celebrating-murder-charlie-kirk) ways to violence aimed at the “other side,” which their opponents interpret as proof of pervasive sickness and immorality. The result of all this filtering is that [both](https://x.com/allenanalysis/status/1934637598254743723) [groups](https://x.com/MsKristaMonroe/status/1919432329728045359) can end up genuinely wondering, “Why is the other side so violent? Why do so many of them support violence?”

Influencing these views is an instinct many of us have to downplay the significance of violence associated with our group, even as we consider violence associated with the other side hugely consequential. If someone kills a political figure on the other side, we might be quick to imagine a deranged, mentally unwell individual. But if someone kills a political figure on our side, there can be a strong temptation to give it great meaning and quickly designate “them” as all culpable.

The number of people who have committed politically motivated murder in recent decades is extremely small relative to the size of our population. We should recognize that even in the most unified country, there will always be some people drawn to hate and violence. Moreover, many in the media and political realm [vastly overstate](https://behavior-podcast.com/no-there-isnt-high-support-for-political-violence-in-america-sean-westwood/) the number of Americans who actually support political violence.

It’s natural for violent events to upset and scare us. But we should consider whether we’re overreacting to what are rare incidents of violence, statistically speaking, in an otherwise very peaceful country, and how our tendency to [cherry-pick bad behaviors](https://www.betterconflictbulletin.org/p/how-many-people-actually-approve) and see the worst in each other can amplify divides—and even lead to [self-fulfilling prophecies](https://buildersmovement.org/2024/04/10/civil-war-movie-reactions-can-it-happen-in-america/).

**2. Class and cultural stereotypes**

The divide is also heavily influenced by education and class. Democrats [tend to have](https://www.pewresearch.org/politics/2025/06/26/voting-patterns-in-the-2024-election/) higher levels of formal education and are more concentrated in high-income, professional sectors and urban areas. Republicans, by contrast, are overrepresented in [working-class](https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/meet-the-press/gop-rapidly-becoming-blue-collar-party-here-s-what-means-n1258468), rural, and religious communities and are less likely to hold advanced degrees.

These differences help each side create [negative, oversimplified stories](https://thefulcrum.us/bridging-common-ground/political-language-polarization) about the other.

On the left, it’s common to hear that Republicans and Trump supporters are “[anti-science](https://thereader.mitpress.mit.edu/why-science-cant-fix-politics/),” easily manipulated, or even [in a cult.](https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/politics/ex-msnbc-host-joy-reid-issues-brutal-verdict-of-maga-voters-over-loyalty-to-trump/ar-AA1IIWrO) They’re willfully ignorant, duped by conspiracy theories, or too intellectually backward to see what’s obvious to “smarter,” more educated people. You’ll find liberals [saying things](https://x.com/spinfisher/status/1948077839967985740) like, “Of course education makes you more politically liberal; that’s because conservatism is backwards.”

On the right, it’s often the inverse: liberals are “out-of-touch elites” captured by academic jargon and niche activist ideas. They’re arrogant, disconnected from the lives of “normal” Americans, and smugly dismissive of, or even [hostile toward](https://whyy.org/articles/trump-turns-virus-conversation-into-us-vs-them-debate/), people who aren’t like them.

Again, some of these narratives may contain elements of truth—but in the hands of highly angry political actors, they will often involve worst-case interpretations and excessive contempt. What’s missing is empathy and nuance: understanding that, by and large, people on the “other side” have real, defensible fears and frustrations—and that each group’s fears [influence](https://defusingamericananger.substack.com/p/republicans-and-democrats-play-a) the other’s.

**3. Accusations of hate**

Democrats and Republicans [both believe](https://osf.io/preprints/psyarxiv/d6bpe_v1) that people on the other side hate them much more than they do. This is one of many self-reinforcing elements of our conflict. When we think, “They hate us,” we are naturally inclined to act in more hostile ways towards “them.” This in turn encourages “them” to treat “us” worse, which makes us treat them worse, and on and on we continue down a doom spiral of toxic conflict.

***

[![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!b4vy!,w_1456,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F5e8ff4ca-62df-4c0d-91d2-859e2eff8791_1506x784.png)](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!b4vy!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F5e8ff4ca-62df-4c0d-91d2-859e2eff8791_1506x784.png)

{{caption: Diagram from my book Defusing American Anger}}

***

In the course of working on reducing polarization, I’ve talked to many Republicans who focus on the toxicity they’ve seen and personally experienced from liberals. It’s true that there are many pieces of evidence one can find to support that narrative. For example, surveys show that Democrats are more likely to [cut off friendships](https://www.axios.com/2021/12/08/poll-political-polarization-students)—or even [family members](https://www.theargumentmag.com/p/when-americans-bite-their-tongues)—for political reasons. Some Republicans are tempted to use this as another building block for the “this is all Democrats’ fault” narrative.

However, another way of interpreting that statistic is that many Democrats (and [others, too](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Republicans_who_opposed_the_Donald_Trump_2024_presidential_campaign)) are turned off by Trump’s divisive personality and by those who support him even in the face of it (or who even emulate his confrontational and even [dehumanizing](https://www.vox.com/science-and-health/2017/6/7/15755852/eric-trump-not-people-dehumanization) rhetoric).

Group differences can leave many of us concluding with certainty, “See, this shows this is all their fault!” In these moments, we should try our best to strive for humility and to remember that the complexity of the world, and of conflict, makes it easy for us to see what we seek to find but harder to see the best in our adversaries.

**4. Cultural vs. political power**

Over at least the past few decades, politically liberal people and ideas have come to [dominate key cultural institutions](https://rosselliotbarkan.com/p/the-left-owns-culture-the-right-owns) like academia, journalism, and the entertainment industry. This imbalance in cultural power has led to an [abundance](https://www.beyondintractability.org/burgess-afpwebinar-sum1) of insults and provocations aimed at conservatives, intentionally or unintentionally, generated by the people in those institutions.

That cultural power imbalance sometimes augments other group differences. For example, many conservatives believe there exists a powerful politically liberal establishment—one that at best [misunderstands](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2019/01/18/nearly-three-quarters-of-republicans-say-the-news-media-dont-understand-people-like-them/) them and at worst disdains them. Feeling like an underdog fighting a vast, culturally dominant adversary can generate more support for an aggressive, contemptuous personality like Trump’s. For many of his supporters, his belligerence isn’t necessarily a flaw but rather a justified form of defiance against an establishment that is entirely against them.

But while liberals have dominated the culture for at least the past decade, they control few levers of political power at this moment. Consider America’s key institutions: the presidency, U.S. Senate, U.S. House, Supreme Court, governorships, and state legislatures. Republicans have more power than Democrats in every single one, and many Democrats fear they may be essentially [locked out of power](https://www.vox.com/2018/7/2/17513520/court-packing-explained-fdr-roosevelt-new-deal-democrats-supreme-court) in [key institutions](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2025/08/25/us/politics/electoral-college-seats-republicans-democrats-redistricting.html) in the near future.

So, although they continue to hold immense cultural power, many Democrats likely feel powerless in the face of Trump’s second term, especially when he has the support of Congress and, often, the Supreme Court too.

Again, regardless of whose views and concerns are more correct, the point is that it's easy for people to build vastly different narratives depending on what facts and moral weightings they use.

***

If we continue to treat each other with great arrogance and contempt, we'll continue to make missteps, convinced that we’re helping extinguish the danger when in fact we’re feeding it with more kindling.

To address this threat we face, we must first understand how it spreads: in the warped stories we tell ourselves about our opponents. Humans are skilled storytellers. We’re good at taking new tidbits of information and fitting them into our existing narratives. In the age of [the internet](https://defusingamericananger.substack.com/p/how-does-internet-communication-divide), it is easier than ever before to use these bits to construct and bolster our preferred narratives. Decent people build stories from various facts and ideas that make sense to them—and many come to view those who have different stories with contempt, accelerating the blaze.

This is how we so easily fall for the “it’s obviously all their fault” framings that keep us mired in toxicity and contempt. Almost everyone believes they are on the side of good, but it’s often hard to see that simple fact in our adversaries. Only when we understand them as people who also believe their views to be good and righteous, the same as ourselves, will we be better positioned to combat our opponents³ without dehumanizing, to work to persuade others instead of provoke, and to stop feeding the dangerous blaze the vast majority of us wish to contain.

***[Zachary Elwood](https://defusingamericananger.substack.com/) is the host of the psychology podcast [People Who Read People](https://behavior-podcast.com/) and the author of*** ***[Defusing American Anger](https://american-anger.com).***

¹ Our political divides clearly are complex and can't cleanly be broken down into concepts of 'Republican' vs 'Democrat,' or even 'left' versus 'right.' (I myself [don't believe in the left-right spectrum](https://behavior-podcast.com/is-the-left-right-spectrum-concept-a-matrix-like-illusion/).) I use 'Republican' and 'Democrat' in this and other work as simple stand-ins for our polarized divides. This is defensible because our toxic conflict largely boils down to whether someone feels drawn to supporting Republican or Democrat leaders.

² The biggest objection I hear to depolarization efforts is that people think it means embracing what they see as a false equivalency—a stance that “both sides are equally bad.” But it’s possible to reject the idea that both sides have contributed equally while acknowledging that both Democrats and Republicans have, in fact, played some role in perpetuating our current conflict.

³ If you'd like tips for doing activism in less polarizing ways, see [8 Tips for Activists Who Want to Reduce Polarization](https://defusingamericananger.substack.com/p/8-tips-for-activists-who-want-to)
